top_categories.workout_context: Pony Xpress’s colorado high desert and foothills gravel and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Pony Xpress rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
At 100 miles, Pony Xpress punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Pony Xpress when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Pony Xpress. Make this intensity feel like home.
Racing Pony Xpress isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Pony Xpress’s high desert gravel, foothills demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Every session at Pony Xpress intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Pony Xpress’s 7,300ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
At 100 miles, Pony Xpress rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what Pony Xpress’s colorado high desert and foothills gravel delivers on race day.
The Norwegian double-threshold method builds the sustained power base for Pony Xpress — massive training stimulus without the recovery cost of VO2max work.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Pony Xpress’s 100 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.altitude: Pony Xpress with 7,300ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%. High altitude (6000-8800 feet).
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Pony Xpress requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on colorado high desert and foothills gravel to build confidence. Expect: high desert gravel, foothills, mining country.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on VO2max, TT Threshold, and Durability to prepare you for 100 miles of colorado high desert and foothills gravel in Cokedale, Colorado.
